facts.text: The facts are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are number in dispute and may be briefly narrated. The petitioner., Balaji, his six soils and his wife,

facts.text: Petitioner Balaji, his six sons and wife Godawaribai constituted a Joint Hindu family.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner., Balaji, his six soils and his wife, by name Godawaribai, companystituted a Joint Hindu family. The family was a trading family and it had, besides business in money lend

facts.text: The family was a trading family with business in money lending and considerable agricultural lands.

anchor.surface_text: The family was a trading family and it had, besides business in money lending, companysiderable agricultural lands. On November 23, 1946, two of his sons became divided from the family.

facts.text: On November 23, 1946, two of his sons became divided from the family.

anchor.surface_text: On November 23, 1946, two of his sons became divided from the family. In the year 1951, through the intervention of mediators the other members of the family were also divided

facts.text: In the year 1951, through the intervention of mediators the other members of the family were also divided.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1951, through the intervention of mediators the other members of the family were also divided and another major member started a separate business on his own.

facts.text: Another major member started a separate business on his own after the division.

anchor.surface_text: and another major member started a separate business on his own. Thereafter, the petitioner and his wife formed themselves into a partnership to carry on their business

facts.text: Petitioner and his wife formed a partnership and admitted their three minor sons to the benefits thereof.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the petitioner and his wife formed themselves into a partnership to carry on their business and admitted their three minor sons to the benefits thereof On September 22, 1952, a partnership deed

facts.text: On September 22, 1952, a partnership deed was executed giving an equal share to each of the partners.

anchor.surface_text: On September 22, 1952, a partnership deed was executed giving an equal share to each of the partners. On the basis of the partnership deed, in respect of the assessment year 1952-53 the petitioner filed

facts.text: For assessment year 1952-53, petitioner filed applications under s.25A for partition recognition and s.26A for registration before ITO Wardha.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the partnership deed, in respect of the assessment year 1952-53 the petitioner filed two applications before the Income-tax Officer, Wardha, one under s. 25-A of the Act for recognizing

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay ordered on September 3, 1958 that partition was recognized and firm granted registration.

anchor.surface_text: Both the applications were finally ordered by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, by its order dated September 3, 1958, that is, the parti. tion was recognized and the firm was granted registration.

facts.text: For assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55, Income-tax Department registered the firm under s.26A.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 also, the Income-tax Department registered the firm under s. 26-A of the Act.

facts.text: Assessment proceedings for 1952-53, 1953-54, 1954-55 pending before concerned Income-tax authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment proceedings in respect of the said three years are pending before the companycerned Income-tax authorities.

facts.text: For assessment year 1955-56, ITO allowed registration but determined total income of petitioner at Rs. 2,44,625 against returned Rs. 58,232.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1955-56 also, the Income-tax Officer allowed the registration of the firm, but determined the total income of the petitioner at Rs. 2,44,625 as against the total income returned

facts.text: Disparity in assessment arose because ITO included share income of wife and three minor sons in petitioner's total income.

anchor.surface_text: by him at Rs. 58,232. The disparity arose because, while the assessee excluded from his total income the income of the partnership falling to the shares of his wife and three minor sons, the Income-tax

arguments.claim: Entry 54 in the Federal Legislative List of the Government of India Act, 1935, did not confer on the Legislature any power to tax A on the income of B and therefore the sub-section was ultra vires the Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the petitioner contended that Entry 54 in the Federal Legislative List of the Government of India Act, 1935, did not confer on the Legislature any power to tax A on the income of B and, therefore, the sub-section was ultra vires the Legislature.

arguments.claim: Express terms of the Entry did not restrict legislative power to tax only the income of the person assessed; what could be taxed was income; nothing prevented imposing incidence of tax on person other than whose income assessed; alternatively distinction between taxability and machinery for collection with intimate nexus between individual, wife and minor sons.

arguments.claim: Entry 54 authorizes imposition of tax and also enactments which prevent evasion of tax imposed.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that the Entries in the Lists are not powers but are only fields of legislation, and that widest import and significance must be given to the, language used by Parliament in the various Entries.

arguments.court_reasoning: classification reasonable: intelligible differentia (prone to fraud/evasion) with rational relation to object (prevent tax evasion); net cast wider but necessary; distinguished US case Hoeper on facts and social context; followed Amina Umma

arguments.claim: Classification under s.16(3)(a)(i) founded on intelligible differentia distinguishing partnerships with wife/minor children (used as cloak for fraud) from others; differentia has rational relation to object of preventing tax evasion.

arguments.claim: Even if genuine partnerships exist, classification reasonable as no sub-classification genuine/non-genuine possible without defeating purpose.

anchor.surface_text: But there is no classification between genuine and non-genuine cases the classification is between cases of partnership between husband, wife and or minor children, whether genuine or not, and partnerships between others.

holdings.text: Sub-section  3  a  1  and  ii  was therefore enacted for preventing evasion of tax and was well within the companypetence of the Federal Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature accepted those recommendations and the loopholes were sought to be plugged by enacting the said sub-section. Sub-section  3  a  1  and  ii  was therefore enacted for preventing evasion of tax and was well within the companypetence of the Federal Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 54 authorizes enactments to prevent evasion of tax; provision historically enacted post-1936 Commission recommendations to plug loopholes from fictitious family partnerships reducing tax liability.

anchor.surface_text: With respect we, give our full assent to the said observations. We, therefore, reject this contention. The next attack on the validity of the provisions is based upon Art. 19  1   f  and  g  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification founded on intelligible differentia (family partnerships prone to fraud vs. others) with rational relation to preventing tax evasion; wider net necessary to avoid sub-classification defeating purpose; Indian social conditions justify unlike US Hoeper case; follows Amina Umma.

holdings.text: We cannot, therefore, accept broad contention of the learned Additional Solicitor-General that a tax law cannot be questioned on the ground that it infringes Art. 19 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot, therefore, accept broad contention of the learned Additional Solicitor-General that a tax law cannot be questioned on the ground that it infringes Art. 19 of the Constitution. Even so the learned Additional Solicitor-General contended that the provisions of  s. 16  3   a   1  and  ii  of the Act constituted only reasonable restrictions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arts. 265 and 13(1) require tax laws to be valid and consistent with Part III; precedents (Yasin, Himmatlal, Kochuni, Thathunni Moopil Nair) hold tax impositions infringing fundamental rights void.

holdings.text: In these circumstances, we cannot say that the provisions of s. 16 3  of the Act impose an unreasonable restriction on the fundamental rights of the petitioner under Art. 19 1  f  and  g  of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we cannot say that the provisions of s. 16 3  of the Act impose an unreasonable restriction on the fundamental rights of the petitioner under Art. 19 1  f  and  g  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying V.G. Row test, restrictions reasonable: target evasion via family partnerships, limited to dependents, no bar to inter se adjustments, higher slabs offset by public benefit and ultimate burden on wife/minors.
